defaultProjects.name: Ka Papa Lo‘i o Kānewai and Ka Papa Loʻi ʻo Punaluʻu
defaultProjects.description: All groups are encouraged to participate in the normal work at either loʻi.  We usually start visiting groups by sharing stories of Kāne and Kanaloa, a lesson on the present ahupuaʻa, and the history of the site.  Next, a short hike/walk to the poʻowai will be taken to explain the water system and how the water is diverted to the loʻi.  A quick lesson on the water cycle is also covered.  Then the work begins with picking leaves for fertilizer, hehihehi i ka loʻi, puʻepuʻe and clearing the ʻauwai system.  Visitors will learn the parts of kalo, along with a few ʻōlelo noʻeau and ʻōlelo nane.

defaultProjects.name: Honolulu Botanical Gardens
defaultProjects.description: The mission of Honolulu Botanical Gardens is to plan, and develop, curate, maintain and study documented collections of tropical plants in an aesthetic setting for the purpose of: conservation, botany, horticulture, education, and passive recreation. There is always a steady amount of work or teaching opportunities within every Botanical Garden. The Honolulu Botanical gardens are located all around the island of Oahu.

defaultProjects.name: Makiki Arboretum Trail Plant Search
defaultProjects.description: Hike through Makiki and search for plants and learn of the local fauna in Hawaii. Tour guides will lead the way as we search and record the plants we find. Snacks will be provided for children. We advise volunteers to bring water

defaultProjects.name: Reforestation and Afforestation in Kwahu Mountains
defaultProjects.description: Help the climate by growing seedlings and planting trees in the communities affected by deforestation and climate change. Work with the local community to educate and provide a long term chain of reforestation. Gain a new family, living in shared volunteer housing gives you the perfect chance to make life long friends across the globe. Make unforgettabe memories travelling with your fellow volunteers at weekends to places such as Mole Safari Park, Cape Coast Castle & Boti Waterfall.

defaultProjects.name: He'eia Estuary Restoration Project
defaultProjects.description: Located on He'eia State Park (currently managed by Kama 'āina Kids), will take place at the mouth of He'eia Stream in an five acre area dominated by non-native species including mangrove and hau bush where both species have encroached on the stream corridor, making it nearly impassable. Replacement of native plant species aid in erosion control, filtration of storm water runoff, and provide habitat for native species.

defaultProjects.name: Kaha Garden
defaultProjects.description: Kaha Garden is a native xeriscape garden located in urban Kailua and maintained solely by community volunteers.  Volunteers at Kaha Garden are taught to identify native plants, learn their growing patterns, how to properly propagate, and where to plant different species to maximize their ecological benefits.  Community workdays are held quarterly at this site. This event is ideal for volunteers of all ages or with limited time to donate, volunteers can come & go as their schedule allows.

defaultProjects.name: Trees For Kaimuki
defaultProjects.description: TFHF has teamed up with EnVision Kaimukī, the City and County of Honolulu’s Urban Forestry Division, Smart Trees Pacific, the National Park Service, The Outdoor Circle, and other partners on this new community-based initiative. The concept behind this initiative is twofold: 1) Develop a Sense of Community Ownership & Pride – Involve residents and business owners /employees in the planning, planting, and caring for new trees, 2) Model for Other Communities – A successful effort in a single community can then serve as a replicable and inviting model for other communities

defaultProjects.name: Hawaii Forest Industry Association
defaultProjects.description: Adult and youth groups from the community and educational institutions are invited to contact the Hawai‘i Forest Industry Association to volunteer at the ongoing dryland forest restoration project. Tasks may include planting seedlings, removing alien weeds, constructing trails, and similar work. Volunteers may be able to participate in a periodically scheduled “work day” on the site, or special arrangements may be possible.

defaultProjects.name: Honolulu Zoo Children's Discovery Forest
defaultProjects.description: HFIA, Hawai‘i Forest Institute (HFI), and community partners are planning the Honolulu Zoo Children’s Discovery Forest, which will be created at the Honolulu Zoo in Waikiki on the Island of O‘ahu. The project site is located near the zoo entrance, adjacent to the future site of a Native Hawaiian Village. The Discovery Forest will be a representation of natural systems, creating a scene of Hawai‘i before the arrival of humans. The exhibit will be designed to demonstrate culturally significant Hawaiian plant species, the significance of place, and the kuleana of mālama ‘āina by integrating traditional Hawaiian forest ecosystems, forest stewardship opportunities, and innovative land-based education for residents and visitors.

defaultProjects.name: Organic Farm Living, Learning & Helping (Hawaii)
defaultProjects.description: We are a 4 acre NO SPRAY small family farm in Honolulu, HI in the town of Hawaii Kai. This farm has been in the family for almost 40 years. My grandmother is still alive and this is where I grew up as a child. On a clear day you can view a beautiful sunset. If you are willing, you will learn why it`s so important to grow your own food at home. We live on an island and if the ships stop coming we have to learn how to survive and be sustainable. Oahu has many different cultures so if you like to explore the island then you will have a great cultural experience.

defaultProjects.name: Maui Farm Community Programs
defaultProjects.description: Farm-based programs utilize farming and gardening activities to improve the mental, emotional, spiritual and physical health of participants, while helping people rediscover their connection to nature in positive ways that facilitate their personal growth and development. Individuals of all ages learn the importance of appreciating and caring for our natural resources, growing our own healthy food, and understanding the importance of sustainability efforts. Through hands-on learning, we teach sustainable agriculture practices and cultural values that support children, youth and adults in becoming good stewards of the ʻaina (land), while encouraging environmental awareness and stewardship.

defaultProjects.name: VOLUNTEERING AT LAHAINA FAMILY FARMS
defaultProjects.description: Lahaina Family Farms is a developing farm, so the tasks include but are not limited to: invasive species removal, native plant restoration, dryland forest management, garden tending, planting + harvesting, animal care, improvement projects

defaultProjects.name: Haleakalā National Park Hawaii Volunteers
defaultProjects.description: Volunteers are essential members of the Haleakalā National Park team. They further the preservation of the park by doing a variety of jobs across all divisions of the park, from interpretation to resource management, facility maintenance, and more! Volunteers help the park by being present for visitors on the trails, monitoring and removing invasive plant species, protecting vulnerable wildlife and habitat, and assisting park operations across the board.The majority of our opportunities are geared towards people who live on the island of Maui and are able to commute into the park. Housing for volunteer opportunities is not provide.

defaultProjects.name: Friends of Haleakala National Park
defaultProjects.description: Volunteers will help park horticulturist with jobs involving caring for the rare, endemic plants being propagated, such as transplanting, weeding, cleaning and preparing seeds for storage or planting, and some pot washing.  The park recycles pots which have to be carefully cleaned to prevent the spread of plant diseases. There may sometimes be some out planting, but most of the service work is done inside, and participants can drive up to the location of the work.  The workday is 9:00 to noon the first Tuesday of each month.    To sign up or to learn more,  please call Mary SantaMaria at (808)572-1584 and leave a message.

defaultProjects.name: KA‘ENA WEED CONTROL
defaultProjects.description: We will clear koa haole (Leucaena leucocephala) from a sand dune located in the Mokule‘ia section of Ka‘ena Point State Park.  The restoration site is located about half-way between the parking lot and the Natural Area Reserve (NAR) and near a regular haul-out site for Hawaiian monk seals.  We will use folding saws and loppers to cut the weeds and then apply herbicide to the cut stem with drip applicator bottles.  Participants will hike the scenic coast and learn about Ka‘ena’s natural and cultural resources, including nesting Laysan albatross in the NAR.

defaultProjects.name: Volunteer to Plant Trees Abroad
defaultProjects.description: Journey to Auckland, where you’ll care for the stunning beaches, landscapes, and islands there. A focus of the project involves the conservation of traditional Māori land. You’ll work side-by-side with the local community. Duties include planting native trees, removing invasive species, collecting seeds, and composting and mulching. Other duties include beach cleanups and tree planting events with local schools.

defaultPlants.name: 'A'ali'i
defaultPlants.description: A dense shrub (4-8 ft.) with small green leaves and tiny flowers that develop into star shaped papery seed capsules.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Full sun, dry/mesic
defaultPlants.range: ‘A’ali’i is an indigenous plant with a range that starts in the dry coastal lowland areas where it was once the most dominant shrub and up into the wetter mesic forests, on all the main islands except for Kahoʻolawe (where it most likely occurred in the past and presently it is being out planted there), and then dominant again in the upper dry forest and sub-alpine dry forests of Maui and Hawaiʻi.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The seed capsules are highly valued for used in lei weaving, and the red capsules are used for making a red dye. The beautiful wood of ʻaʻaliʻi is very hard and is used for making smaller hand tools and weapons.
defaultPlants.pests: beatles: being by an artifitial light at night helps

defaultPlants.name: 'Akia
defaultPlants.description: Dense shrubs that either grow prostrate or sprawl up to 3-4 ft. tall. They have small oval shaped leaves, greenish-blue in color that is attached to braches which are reddish brown. When in bloom, numerous clusters of tiny yellow flowers develop which eventually turn into small orange or red fruits about ½-3/4 inch in diameter. The flowers have a very musky but distinct scent to them and can be easily smelt from a distance usually more so in the early evening.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Full sun, dry/mesic
defaultPlants.range: This endemic plant can easily be seen in numerous landscapes throughout Honolulu and the rest of the State. This plant, along with naupaka (Scaevola sericea), pohinahina (Vitex rotundifolia), and pualoalo (Hibiscus arnottianus) are among the most used native plants in Hawaiian landscapes today. Although, in the wild it is quite rare, found only in dry, open, often disturbed, lowland or coastal habitats on Kaua’i, O’ahu Molokai, and Maui where it is also reported as far inland as ‘Iao Valley.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Many members of this genus Wikstroemia were used as a narcotic to catch fish. The bark, roots and leaves were pounded and mixed with bait and then thrown in the water to feed the fish; upon ingesting, the fish would swim in a “drunken” state which made them easier to scoop up with a net or to spear. The mashed plant parts are also used in Hawaiian spell casting and sorcery.

defaultPlants.name: 'Aweoweo
defaultPlants.indigenousStatus: Endemic: Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Maui, Lanai, Hawaii, plus Lisianski, Laysan, Necke, French Frigate Shoals, Nihoa.
defaultPlants.description: ‘Aweoweo are typically low shrubs to small trees 2-8ft. tall with light blue/green leaves that are in the shape of a goose’s foot (they belong to the goose foot plant family Chenopodiacae). Sometimes the leaves call be very tiny, about ¼”-1/2″ across or they can be up to 2 inches depending on the growing conditions. Usually less water and more sun will result in smaller, thicker leaves whereas regular watering will make the plant have larger more thin leaves like in the picture. The flowers are very small and are in clusters above the plant. The older stems are usually streaked with red, similar to the fish, but also, when the leaves and flowers are crushed it smells just like the ‘aweoweo fish too! fo’ real! I not joking! But, you have to crush it first. You don’t have to worry about the plant smelling up your yard.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Full sun, dry/mesic
defaultPlants.range: ‘Aweoweo, the plant not the fish, is found in drier, harsh habitats like near the ocean, in the lowland dry forest or all the way up in the sub-alpine shrub land of the large volcanoes like Mauna Kea. Although its species name is oahuense, this endemic plant is found on all of the main Hawaiian Islands except Kaho’olawe (it was probably found there before) but also on most of the Northwestern Hawaiian islands as well.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The young leaves and stems are wrapped in ti leaves and steamed to be eaten in times of famine. The harder wood at the base of the plant can also be shaped in to fish hooks so you can catch ‘aweoweo with ‘aweoweo.

defaultPlants.name: Pili
defaultPlants.indigenousStatus: Endemic: Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Maui, Lanai, Hawaii, plus Lisianski, Laysan, Necke, French Frigate Shoals, Nihoa.
defaultPlants.description: Pili grass forms bunches or tufts of light blueish-green leaf blades which range in height from two to three ft. tall. Their flowers, although insignificant in appearance, form spikelets at the top of the plant and often become tangled amongst each other. This dense cluster of seeds is most likely how the plant received its name since the word pili means to stick or cling to.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Full sun in hot, dry areas
defaultPlants.range: Pili grass is an indigenous plant, or perhaps even a Polynesian introduction that is found in dry open areas, rocky cliffs or slopes near the ocean. It is found throughout the tropics as well as all of the main Hawaiian islands in scattered population. An interesting side note is that many of the Great Plains States utilize pili for in their restorations of grasslands and prairies. Its is probably safe to say that there is more pili grass growing out in those state’s than there is growing here in Hawai’i .
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Pili was used in the past primarily for thatching houses and can still be used today for that purpose. It was also placed on hula altars for Laka in hopes that newly gained knowledge would pili, or stick in their minds.

defaultPlants.name: 'Uki'uki
defaultPlants.indigenousStatus: All HI except Niihau and Kahoolawe
defaultPlants.description: From what I have seen there are two basic forms of ‘uki’uki found through out the state. One form has a more compact growth habit, only about 1-1.5 ft. tall (from now on this one will be referred to as the ‘short’ one) while the other has a taller, less compact look to it and can grow to about 2.5-3 ft. tall (we’ll call this one the ‘taller’ one). Both are beautiful lilies but in their own way. The short one (as seen in the picture above) has dark green leaf blades and when in bloom it sends up a short stalk in the middle of the foliage that is covered with small purple and yellow flowers that once pollinated develop into dark purple or even lavender berries about ½”-1” in diameter. The seeds of this form are black, smooth and extremely glossy. The taller one has lighter green foliage and sends out a taller stalk with much more of the same small flowers but these are usually white and yellow and once they are pollinated the fruit that develop are more transparent looking and not as vibrant purple color, sometimes they look brown and the seeds are not glossy and smooth like the short one, instead they are rough and come in a variety of shapes.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: It does well in practically any growing condition from full sun to practically full shade, outdoors to indoors, moderate water to little water, just about anything. I prefer to use it as an accent plant around large boulders or at the base of larger plants and shrubs.
defaultPlants.range: All forms of ‘uki’uki are classified as indigenous meaning that they are native to Hawai’i but also other parts of the world. These plants are found in many different vegetation zones from lowland dry forests to higher wet forests, in fact, I’ve seen it growing near the ocean around naupaka as well as in the marsh on the top of Mount Ka’ala and practically everywhere else in between. ‘Uki’uki is found on all the main islands except Ni’ihau and Kaho’olawe, although they most likely occurred there in the past.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The leaves can be used for thatching while the berries of the short one make a nice bluish-purple dye for kapa while the taller one usually makes a yellowish-brown dye. As delicious as the berries look, don’t eat them they don’t taste ono at all and they turn your whole mouth blue, trust me I know.
defaultPlants.pests: white scales and mealy bugs;  If you do notice them on the underside of the leaves, they can be manually removed by either shooting them off with water or by cleaning them off with your fingers using soapy water

defaultPlants.name: Wiliwili
defaultPlants.description: Deciduous trees up to 40 feet tall with light green leaves, reddish-tan bark, and creamy green to dark orange-colored flowers that develop into seed pods with bright orange seeds. Sharp thorns develop on the trunk and branches. The thorns begin to fade as the tree ages.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Wiliwili does well in any sunny, dry area. After established does not need to be watered
defaultPlants.range: This endemic plant is found on coastal-lowland dry forests on all the main islands.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The light wood is used culturally for constructing canoe outriggers, floats and surfboards. The seeds and individual flowers were strung into lei.

defaultPlants.name: Awapuhi
defaultPlants.description: Awesome understory or full sun specimen.  Watch out, like most gingers it has the ability to take over an area.  It also is deciduous meaning that it annually loses its foliage after flowering and lays dormant for about 3 months but will pop up bigger and fuller the next season!
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Medicinally, for cooking (leaves wrapped and flavored meat), drinking and to make one smell better.

defaultPlants.name: Pohinahina
defaultPlants.description: A sprawling shrub (2-3ft.) with rounded leaves that are silvery-green in color on top and whitish underneath. Small purple flowers form clusters which emerge at the top of the plant and sit in a pocket of the top leaves, very cool looking and it is definitely a striking site when a large area is in full bloom.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: thrive in full sun
defaultPlants.range: This is an indigenous plant meaning that it is native to Hawaii as well as other parts of the Pacific, even Japan! Here it is found on sandy coasts of all the main islands except Kaho’olawe although it may have occurred there in the past.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The fragrant leaves of this plant can be layered between folded kapa to repel insects but now days I guess you can put them in your BVD drawers. The leaves and flowers can also be arranged in head leis (lei po’o), very nice.

defaultPlants.name: Ohia Lehua - Ohia - Lehua Mamo- Lehua - Mamo
defaultPlants.indigenousStatus: Endemic: All HI except Ni’ihau and Kaho’olawe
defaultPlants.description: Of the five different species of ‘ohi’a recognized, this is the most variable. The leaves of this plant range from 1/2″ to 3″, they can also be very glabrous or very hairy. The new leaves or liko range in color from dark purple, almost black to red, gold and everything in between. Some plants bush out while others grow to over 80 ft. tall. The ‘ohi’a or lehua as some people call, are best known for its flowers. They are just as variable as the plants themselves. Color ranges from very dark red (lehua ‘apane) all the way through to yellow (lehua mamo) or even white (lehua kea) according to some legends. I’ve even seen a flower that was dark red at the base, gradually faded to yellow and finally ended with greenish tips, it was unbelievable.
defaultPlants.range: The ‘ohi’a is an endemic plant found on all of the main islands except Ni’ihau and Kaho’olawe, at least that’s where they’re found today, They were most likely found on those other islands in the past. Today ‘ohi’a are found mainly at higher elevations, there are some places where you can still see them on the coast and in lowland dry forests but these instances are very rare. Originally, there range extended from sea level all the way up to around 6,500 ft.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: One of the most important woods in Hawaiian culture, ‘ohi’a was used for a number of things: In house construction, rafters and posts were made of it; decking, seats and gunwales of canoes were also made of ‘ohi’a; various leis either used the flowers, flower buds or leaf buds of ‘ohi’a; it decorated hula altars for the god Kuka’ohi’a and religious images called ki’i were made of ‘ohi’a as well.

defaultPlants.name: Awapuhi kuahiwi
defaultPlants.description: Awapuhi kuahiwi, also known as Shampoo Ginger, is a common plant in Hawaii. It is a herbaceous perennial plant that can grow up to 6 feet tall. The plant has a clumping growth habit, and the leaves are long and lance-shaped, up to 2 feet long. The flowers are cone-shaped, pink or red in color, and emerge from a green bract. The inflorescence is fragrant, and the plant is often used as a natural shampoo.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Awapuhi kuahiwi grows well in partial shade to full sun, and prefers well-draining soil. It can be propagated by division or from rhizomes, and can also be grown from seed.
defaultPlants.range: Awapuhi kuahiwi is indigenous to Hawaii, and can also be found in other tropical regions, such as Southeast Asia.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The rhizomes of Awapuhi kuahiwi have been traditionally used in Hawaii for medicinal purposes, including for soothing stomach aches and relieving headaches. The plant is also used as a natural shampoo and conditioner.
defaultPlants.pests: Awapuhi kuahiwi is relatively pest-free.

defaultPlants.name: Kou
defaultPlants.description: Kou is a small to medium-sized tree that can grow up to 40 feet tall. It has a broad, spreading crown and smooth, grayish bark. The leaves are oval-shaped and glossy, up to 8 inches long, and have a distinctive scent when crushed. The flowers are small and white, and are followed by small, orange or red fruit.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Kou grows well in full sun to partial shade, and prefers well-drained soil. It can be propagated by seed, cuttings, or air layering.
defaultPlants.range: Kou is indigenous to Hawaii, and can also be found in other Pacific islands.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Kou wood was traditionally used in Hawaii for making bowls, calabashes, and other utensils. The wood is hard and durable, and has a beautiful grain. The bark and leaves were also used in traditional medicine.
defaultPlants.pests: Kou is relatively pest-free.

defaultPlants.name: Maiapilo
defaultPlants.description: Maiapilo is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 20 feet tall. It has dark green leaves that are glossy and leathery with a smooth texture. The flowers are fragrant, white, and have long stamens that protrude out of the center of the flower. The fruit is a round berry that is green when unripe and turns yellow when ripe. The berry is edible and has a sweet and tangy taste.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Maiapilo grows in dry and rocky areas in lowland to montane forests. It prefers well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade. It is drought tolerant and can survive with little water once established.
defaultPlants.range: Maiapilo is endemic to the Hawaiian Islands and can be found on all the main islands except for Kahoʻolawe and Niʻihau.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Maiapilo has a number of cultural uses. The fruit is eaten fresh or used to make jelly or jam. The bark and leaves were used to make medicine for treating stomach ailments, and the wood was used for making tools and weapons.
defaultPlants.pests: Maiapilo is relatively pest-free, but may be susceptible to fungal diseases in wet conditions.

defaultPlants.name: Akiohala
defaultPlants.description: A medium sized hibiscus about eight feet tall with rough leaves that are slight to moderately lobed. New stems, flower buds, and leaf surface are densely pubescent. They have awesome flowers that emerge on tall stems which stand up above the rest of the plant. Each flower is large and has light purple/pink petals with a dark purple center and staminal column. Once pollinated, the calyx will turn brown and be filled with many small, shiny brown seeds.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Maiapilo grows in dry and rocky areas in lowland to montane forests. It prefers well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade. It is drought tolerant and can survive with little water once established.
defaultPlants.range: Kauai, Oahu, Maui, Hawaii
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Flowers can be used medicinally as a laxative and also for a dye, while the bark can be stripped and woven into cordage.

defaultPlants.name: Nohu
defaultPlants.description: Low-growing ground cover with bright yellow flowers that average in 2 inches in diameter.  Once pollinated flowers develop in to sun shaped seed capsules that are covered with very hard and sharp spines.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Coastal
defaultPlants.range: This native Hawaiian plant is uncommonly found along sandy and rocky coast lines of most islands, including the north western Hawaiian islands.

defaultPlants.name: Ala He'e
defaultPlants.description: Ala He'e is a native plant that can grow as an epiphyte or a terrestrial plant. It has succulent stems and leaves that can be green or red in color. The leaves are thick and leathery with a glossy sheen. The flowers are small and grow in spikes that can be green or white in color. The plant is a popular choice for terrariums and as a houseplant due to its small size and ease of care.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Ala He'e can be grown in bright, indirect light or low light conditions. It prefers well-draining soil and should be watered when the soil is dry to the touch. The plant can tolerate some neglect and can go without water for several weeks. It is sensitive to cold temperatures and should be kept in temperatures above 60 degrees Fahrenheit.
defaultPlants.propagation: The plant can be propagated by stem cuttings or by dividing the root ball.
defaultPlants.range: Ala He'e is native to Hawaii and can be found growing in the understory of mesic and wet forests on all the main islands except Ni'ihau and Kaho'olawe.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: There are no known cultural uses for Ala He'e.
defaultPlants.pests: Ala He'e is generally pest-resistant but can be susceptible to mealybugs and spider mites. These pests can be controlled by washing the leaves with a solution of water and mild soap.

defaultPlants.name: Koa
defaultPlants.description: Koa is a large tree that can grow up to 100 ft. tall and is one of the most iconic and valuable trees in Hawaii. The bark is light gray and has a characteristic wavy pattern. The leaves are bright green, with long, narrow leaflets, and the tree produces small, pale yellow flowers that are fragrant and attract bees. Koa trees produce hard, durable wood that has been highly valued for centuries by Hawaiians for making canoes, weapons, and furniture.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Koa grows best in well-drained, fertile soil and full sun, but it can also tolerate some shade. It is found in dry to wet forests at elevations ranging from sea level to around 6,000 ft.
defaultPlants.range: Koa is found on all of the main Hawaiian islands except Ni'ihau and Kaho'olawe. It is also found on other Pacific islands, including Fiji and Samoa.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Koa wood is highly prized by Hawaiians for its beauty and durability, and has been used for centuries to make canoes, weapons, furniture, and other items. In ancient times, only chiefs and high-ranking individuals were allowed to possess koa wood items. Today, koa is still highly valued and is used to make a variety of crafts, from ukuleles to bowls and furniture.
defaultPlants.pests: Koa is susceptible to a number of pests, including the koa moth, the koa bug, and the koa looper. These pests can damage the leaves, bark, and wood of the tree, and can sometimes cause defoliation or death of the tree. To prevent pest infestations, it is important to maintain healthy growing conditions for the tree, such as adequate water and fertilizer, and to prune and remove any infected branches or foliage.

defaultPlants.name: Ulei
defaultPlants.description: Ulei is a small tree or shrub that can grow up to 10 feet tall. It has leathery leaves that are small and oval-shaped. The flowers are small and white, and they form clusters at the tips of the branches. The fruit is a small, dry, hard capsule that contains one or two seeds. Ulei is an important plant for native birds and insects, as it provides both food and habitat.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Ulei prefers well-drained soils and can grow in full sun or partial shade. It is tolerant of drought and salt spray, making it a good choice for coastal areas. Ulei can be propagated from seed or cuttings, and it can be pruned to maintain its shape.
defaultPlants.range: Ulei is endemic to the Hawaiian Islands, and it can be found on all the main islands except Ni'ihau and Kaho'olawe. It is typically found in dry to mesic forests and shrublands, but it can also be found in wetter forests at higher elevations.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Ulei has several traditional uses in Hawaiian culture. The bark and leaves were used to make a tea that was believed to have medicinal properties, and the wood was used to make tools and weapons. The plant was also used in hula ceremonies and other cultural practices.
defaultPlants.pests: Ulei is relatively pest-free, but it can be susceptible to root rot if grown in poorly-drained soils.

defaultPlants.name: Haole Koa
defaultPlants.description: Haole Koa is a fast-growing, nitrogen-fixing tree that can grow up to 50 ft tall. The tree has compound leaves with small leaflets that fold up at night. Haole Koa produces showy clusters of white flowers, followed by pods containing seeds. The tree is highly adaptable and can grow in a wide range of habitats, from wet to dry environments. However, it is considered an invasive species in Hawai'i as it can outcompete native plants and alter ecosystems.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Haole Koa is tolerant of a range of soil types and can grow in full sun to partial shade. It prefers well-drained soils, but can also tolerate periodically flooded soils. The tree is drought-tolerant once established and can withstand strong winds and salt spray.
defaultPlants.range: Haole Koa is native to Central and South America, but has been introduced to many parts of the world, including Hawai'i.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The wood of haole koa is used for furniture, cabinetry, and musical instruments. The tree is also used as a shade tree, windbreak, and erosion control plant.
defaultPlants.pests: Haole Koa can be susceptible to a number of pests, including spider mites, thrips, and whiteflies. It can also be affected by various diseases, including root rot and cankers.

defaultPlants.name: Hala
defaultPlants.description: Hala is a small to medium-sized tree that can grow up to 30 ft tall. It has long, spiky leaves that grow in clusters at the end of its branches. The tree produces an unusual, round fruit with a spiky exterior that is often used in Polynesian cultural practices. The leaves of the hala tree are used in weaving mats, baskets, hats, and other items.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Hala grows best in sandy or loamy soils that are well-drained. It prefers full sun to partial shade and can tolerate salt spray and strong winds. The tree is drought-tolerant and can survive periodic flooding.
defaultPlants.range: Hala is native to the Pacific Islands, including Hawai'i. It can be found in lowland coastal areas, especially near the water's edge.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The fruit of the hala tree is used in Polynesian cultural practices, such as hula and kapa-making. The leaves are used in weaving mats, baskets, hats, and other items. The tree is also used for medicinal purposes, including treating headaches and fever.
defaultPlants.pests: Hala can be susceptible to a number of pests, including mealybugs, spider mites, and scale insects. It can also be affected by various diseases, including leaf spot and root rot.

defaultPlants.name: Kolea
defaultPlants.description: Kolea is a small shrub that can grow up to 10 feet tall. It has glossy, dark green leaves and produces small, round fruit that turns red when mature. The plant is important in Hawaiian culture and is often used in lei making.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Kolea grows best in well-drained soils that are rich in organic matter. It prefers full sun to partial shade and can tolerate salt spray and strong winds. The plant is drought-tolerant and can survive periodic flooding.
defaultPlants.range: Kolea is native to Hawaii and can be found in dry and mesic forests, as well as in coastal areas.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Kolea is important in Hawaiian culture and is often used in lei making. The plant is also used for medicinal purposes, including treating coughs and colds.
defaultPlants.pests: Kolea can be susceptible to a number of pests, including scale insects and mealybugs. It can also be affected by various diseases, including leaf spot and root rot.

defaultPlants.name: Kukui
defaultPlants.description: Kukui is a large tree that can grow up to 80 feet tall. It has large, bright green leaves and produces clusters of small, white flowers that are followed by nuts. The nuts are edible and are used to make kukui nut leis and oil.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Kukui grows best in well-drained soils that are rich in organic matter. It prefers full sun to partial shade and can tolerate salt spray and strong winds. The tree is drought-tolerant and can survive periodic flooding.
defaultPlants.range: Kukui is native to the Pacific Islands, including Hawaii. It can be found in lowland forests and coastal areas.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Kukui is an important tree in Hawaiian culture and is the state tree of Hawaii. The nuts are used to make kukui nut leis and oil, which is used in traditional Hawaiian medicine. The tree is also used for woodworking and as a source of fuel.
defaultPlants.pests: Kukui can be susceptible to a number of pests, including mealybugs and scale insects. It can also be affected by various diseases, including leaf spot and root rot.

defaultPlants.name: Amau
defaultPlants.description: Amau is a large, evergreen fern that can grow up to 15 feet tall. It has fronds that are up to 6 feet long and 1 foot wide, with a bright green color. Amau typically grows in moist, shaded areas, such as along streams or in valleys. It is an important part of the Hawaiian forest ecosystem, providing habitat for birds and other animals.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Amau grows best in moist, well-drained soil in shaded areas. It can tolerate some sun, but too much direct sunlight can damage the fronds. Amau requires regular watering and benefits from occasional fertilization.
defaultPlants.range: Amau is native to Hawai'i and can be found on most of the main islands. It is most common in wet, shaded areas on the windward side of the islands.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Amau was traditionally used by Hawaiians to make hula skirts, capes, and other items. It is also used in contemporary Hawaiian crafts, such as lei-making and weaving. The fern is believed to have medicinal properties and was used to treat a variety of ailments, including headaches and skin conditions.
defaultPlants.pests: Amau can be susceptible to a number of pests, including scale insects and mealybugs. It can also be affected by various diseases, including fungal leaf spot and rust.

defaultPlants.name: Akoko
defaultPlants.description: Akoko is a low-growing shrub that typically grows up to 3 feet tall. It has small, oval-shaped leaves and produces tiny, inconspicuous flowers. Akoko can be found in a variety of habitats, including dry forests, rocky areas, and coastal cliffs. It is an important plant for erosion control and habitat restoration.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Akoko grows best in well-drained soil in full sun to partial shade. It can tolerate a range of soil types, including sandy and rocky soils. Akoko is drought-tolerant but benefits from occasional watering during periods of prolonged dryness.
defaultPlants.range: Akoko is native to Hawai'i and can be found on all of the main islands. It is most common in dry, rocky areas and coastal cliffs.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Akoko was traditionally used by Hawaiians to treat a variety of ailments, including headaches, stomachaches, and toothaches. The plant was also used to make fishing nets and ropes.
defaultPlants.pests: Akoko can be susceptible to a number of pests, including spider mites and whiteflies. It can also be affected by various diseases, including leaf spot and powdery mildew.

defaultPlants.name: Olena
defaultPlants.description: Olena is a perennial herb that grows up to 3 feet tall. It has long, narrow leaves and a rhizomatous root system. The plant produces a bright orange-yellow rhizome that is used as a spice and natural dye. Olena is also known for its medicinal properties and has been used in traditional medicine for centuries.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Olena grows best in tropical and subtropical regions with plenty of rainfall. It prefers well-drained soils and partial shade. The plant can be grown from rhizomes or seed, but rhizome propagation is more common.
defaultPlants.range: Olena is native to Southeast Asia and has been introduced to Hawai'i and other parts of the world.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Olena is used in traditional Hawaiian medicine to treat a variety of ailments, including inflammation, arthritis, and digestive issues. It is also used as a natural dye for clothing and other textiles. The spice derived from the rhizome is a common ingredient in Hawaiian cuisine and is also used in traditional ceremonies.
defaultPlants.pests: Olena is relatively pest-resistant but can be affected by root rot and other fungal diseases.

defaultPlants.name: Uala
defaultPlants.description: Uala, also known as sweet potato, is a vine-like plant that produces edible tubers. It has heart-shaped leaves and can grow up to 10 feet in length. The tubers come in a variety of colors, including orange, purple, and white, and are a staple food in many parts of the world.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Uala prefers well-drained soils that are rich in organic matter. It can be grown in full sun or partial shade and is relatively drought-tolerant. The plant can be propagated from slips or vine cuttings.
defaultPlants.range: Uala is thought to have originated in South America but has been cultivated in Hawai'i and other parts of the world for centuries.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Uala is a staple food in many parts of the world and is used in a variety of dishes, from soups and stews to desserts. It is also used in traditional Hawaiian medicine to treat a variety of ailments. The leaves and stems of the plant are sometimes used in cooking as well.
defaultPlants.pests: Uala can be susceptible to a number of pests and diseases, including sweet potato weevils and fungal infections.

defaultPlants.name: Coconut
defaultPlants.description: Coconut is a large, palm-like tree that can grow up to 100 feet tall. It has long, feathery leaves that can reach up to 18 feet in length, and produces large, round fruit that contain a sweet, nutty flesh and refreshing water. Coconut trees are widely cultivated in tropical regions around the world, and are often associated with beaches and island paradises.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Coconut trees grow best in warm, tropical climates with lots of sunlight and moderate rainfall. They prefer sandy, well-draining soils, and are salt-tolerant. The trees can grow in a variety of soils, but require good drainage to prevent root rot.
defaultPlants.range: Coconut is not indigenous to Hawai'i, but was introduced to the islands by Polynesian voyagers. The trees can now be found throughout the tropics, including Hawai'i.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Coconut is a highly versatile plant that has been used for food, medicine, and other purposes for centuries. In Hawai'i, coconut meat and milk are used in a variety of traditional dishes, including haupia, a coconut milk pudding. The leaves and fibers of the coconut tree are used to make baskets, mats, and thatching for roofs. Coconut oil, which is extracted from the meat of the fruit, is used for cooking, as a skin and hair conditioner, and in a variety of cosmetic products.
defaultPlants.pests: Coconut trees can be susceptible to a number of pests and diseases, including lethal yellowing, which can kill the tree within a few years. The coconut rhinoceros beetle, a serious pest that can cause significant damage to coconut trees, was introduced to Hawai'i in 2013.

defaultPlants.name: Uhiuhi
defaultPlants.description: Uhiuhi is a small to medium-sized tree that can grow up to 30 ft tall. It has glossy, dark green leaves and produces bright yellow flowers in the summer. The tree's wood is prized for its strength and durability, and is used in the construction of canoes, tools, and other items.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Uhiuhi grows best in well-drained soils that are rich in organic matter. It prefers full sun to partial shade and can tolerate salt spray and strong winds. The tree is drought-tolerant and can survive periodic flooding.
defaultPlants.range: Uhiuhi is native to the Hawaiian Islands and can be found in dry to mesic forests on all of the main islands.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The wood of the uhiuhi tree is used in the construction of canoes, tools, and other items. The tree also has medicinal properties and is used to treat a variety of ailments.
defaultPlants.pests: Uhiuhi can be susceptible to a number of pests, including scale insects, mealybugs, and spider mites. It can also be affected by various diseases, including leaf spot and root rot.

defaultPlants.name: Keawe
defaultPlants.description: Keawe is a thorny shrub or small tree that can grow up to 30 ft tall. It has small, yellow flowers and produces flat seed pods. The tree is known for its long, sharp thorns and its dense, spreading branches. Keawe is a nitrogen-fixing plant and is often used for reforestation and erosion control.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Keawe can grow in a variety of soils, from sandy to clay. It prefers full sun and can tolerate drought and salt spray.
defaultPlants.range: Keawe is native to South America but has been introduced to many tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including Hawai'i.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: Keawe has a number of uses in traditional Hawaiian culture, including as a source of wood for carving and as a material for making tools and weapons. The tree is also used for medicinal purposes, including treating infections and wounds.
defaultPlants.pests: Keawe can be susceptible to a number of pests, including scale insects, mealybugs, and spider mites. It can also be affected by various diseases, including leaf spot and root rot.

defaultPlants.name: Hapu'u
defaultPlants.description: Hapu'u is a tree fern native to Hawaii. It can grow up to 20 feet tall and has large fronds that can be over 10 feet long. The trunk of the hapu'u fern is covered in brown scales, giving it a unique appearance. The fronds of the fern are often used in hula, and the trunk is sometimes used for building structures.
defaultPlants.growingConditions: Hapu'u ferns prefer moist, well-drained soil and partial shade. They are often found growing in shady areas of the forest, near streams or other sources of water.
defaultPlants.range: Hapu'u ferns are found in Hawaii, particularly on the islands of Hawaii, Maui, and Kauai.
defaultPlants.culturalUses: The fronds of the hapu'u fern are used in hula, particularly in dances that represent the forest or nature. The trunk of the fern is sometimes used for building structures.
defaultPlants.pests: Hapu'u ferns are relatively pest-free.

defaultForums.title: Soil Quality
defaultForums.leadComment: Discussion about how to keep up good soil quality over time

defaultForums.title: Rainwater
defaultForums.leadComment: Discussion about different ideas/systems to collect and redistribute natural rain water

defaultForums.title: Growing Your Own Food
defaultForums.leadComment: Share tips and advice on how to grow your own food and become more self-sufficient. Discuss the benefits of growing native plants and other crops that are well-suited to your local environment.

defaultForums.title: Protecting Endangered Species
defaultForums.leadComment: Discuss ways to protect and conserve endangered species, such as planting native plants that provide habitat and food for wildlife, reducing human impact on their habitats, and supporting conservation organizations.

defaultForums.title: Sustainable Living
defaultForums.leadComment: Share your ideas and experiences on how to live more sustainably, including reducing your carbon footprint, using renewable energy, and conserving resources. Discuss how to integrate sustainable practices into your daily life.

defaultForums.title: Malama Aina Projects
defaultForums.leadComment: Share information and updates on current conservation projects in your area. Discuss how you can get involved and help protect and restore local ecosystems, such as planting native plants, removing invasive species, and restoring wetlands.

defaultForums.title: Traditional Farming Practices
defaultForums.leadComment: Discuss traditional farming practices and their importance for food security and sustainable agriculture. Share knowledge and techniques for growing crops in harmony with the land, using natural fertilizers and pest control methods, and preserving heirloom varieties.

defaultForums.title: Advocating for Conservation
defaultForums.leadComment: Share your experiences and tips for advocating for conservation policies and initiatives at the local, state, and national levels. Discuss how to build coalitions, engage policymakers, and raise awareness about the importance of conservation and environmental protection.

defaultForums.title: Indoor Plants
defaultForums.leadComment: Discuss how to take care of indoor plants and how they've affected your lifestyle. What indoor plants are easiest to take care of? What plants would be a good addition to a college student's dorm?

defaultForums.title: Carnivorous Plants
defaultForums.leadComment: How to take care of carnivorous plants. These plants require additional attention and are much different to take care of. What are some tips and tricks for taking care of them? Share your experiences with carnivorous plants.
